generif.text: Overexpression of CEACAM6 disrupts tissue architecture and blocks colonocyte differentiation
CEACAM6 subdomains involved in intercellular adhesion activity and subdomains involved in inhibition of cell differentation are identified and their respective activities are independently blocked.

our findings identified CEACAM6, which is regulated by miR-29a/b/c, as an important positive regulator of EMT in pancreatic cancer

Helicobacter pylori HopQ binds the amino-terminal IgV-like domain of human CEACAM1, CEACAM3, CEACAM5 or CEACAM6 proteins, thereby enabling translocation of the major pathogenicity factor CagA into host cells.

Here, the authors identify members of the carcinoembryonic antigen-related cell adhesion molecule (CEACAM) family as receptors of Helicobacter pylori and show that HopQ is the surface-exposed adhesin that specifically binds human CEACAM1, CEACAM3, CEACAM5 and CEACAM6.

name: CEA cell adhesion molecule 6
other_names: carcinoembryonic antigen related cell adhesion molecule 6
carcinoembryonic antigen-related cell adhesion molecule 6 (non-specific cross reacting antigen)

reactome.name: Cell surface interactions at the vascular wall

summary: This gene encodes a protein that belongs to the carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) family whose members are glycosyl phosphatidyl inositol (GPI) anchored cell surface glycoproteins. Members of this family play a role in cell adhesion and are widely used as tumor markers in serum immunoassay determinations of carcinoma. This gene affects the sensitivity of tumor cells to adenovirus infection. The protein encoded by this gene acts as a receptor for adherent-invasive E. coli adhesion to the surface of ileal epithelial cells in patients with Crohn's disease. This gene is clustered with genes and pseudogenes of the cell adhesion molecules subgroup of the CEA family on chromosome 19. [provided by RefSeq, Apr 2014].
